awd_titl_txt: A Database and Analysis of Intergroup Hostility
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to advance understanding of intergroup conflict through assembly of a comprehensive database and through tests of theoretically derived hypotheses using that database.  The database will cover the years 1990-2017 and will avoid some of the limitations of earlier data collections, which relied on official estimates that often underestimated the frequencies of hostile events. The analysis will investigate the effect of community context on how likely intergroup conflict is to occur as well as the effect of hostility on the groups under attack. The database will be available to the public and policymakers. Findings from the analysis will be useful to policymakers, groups facing hostility, and other concerned parties seeking to reduce intergroup hostility in American communities.

Multiple sources and strategies will be used to create the database of hostile events and the communities where these events occurred. Information on the events will be culled from newspapers, FBI statistics, and independent groups and will be coded for characteristics, location, time, and media coverage. This data will be supplemented with GIS data on the event location and survey data on the relevant groups. The spatial and longitudinal database will allow testing of several predictions, for example, concerning the effects of group concentrations and effects of positive advocacy events. These predictions will be tested with appropriate statistical methods and the results will inform theories concerning intergroup relations, civil society and collective action.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Anti-Muslim events (e.g. personal attacks, Mosque defacements, public intimidation) became widespread across the U.S, in the days following the attacks on September 11, 2001. Besides “Hate Crime” indices aimed at chronicling the most serious such events, there exists little available record allowing researchers to do the same for the full panoply of anti-Muslim events before and after 9/11.This project aimed to create a comprehensive database for analyzing what we termed intergroup Muslim hostility events using newspaper records. These include hostile events where a Muslim person or group is identified at the target of the aggression. We also tracked events whose purpose was to support and advocate Muslim citizens and communities—we term them Muslim advocacy events. Data collection and processing is continuing. The initial database we compiled consists of all newspaper reports accessed through Newsbank, an online news archive, for the full year of 2001. The project has also made substantial inroads in coding newspaper reports from the years 1991 and 2011, aimed at generating comparisons 10-years prior and after the 9/11 attacks. We have assembled all newspaper articles in the Newsbank Archive for that 20 year period that are remaining candidates to be searched for containing events of interest based on their content.       

We use the Newsbank archive as our primary data source. Since we needed to search an enormous number of articles to create our full data base for analysis NewsBank agreed to become a sub-contractor, allowing us to identify, with appropriate search terms, all candidate newspaper stories for the years 1990-2016. We identified several hundred thousand candidate articles that were distinguished by state and year before assigned for coding. During the coding process, all newspaper stories for a given state and year were assigned to an undergraduate research assistant. Undergraduate research assistants were trained to distinguish between “events” and “no events” before beginning the coding process. They were trained through a collection of “training articles” and their work verified through the supervision of a graduate research assistant.

We accompkished this coding by devising a protocol based upon our elaborately pre-tested definitions of an ‘event’, proceeding through multiple rounds of coding using examples. These tests and verification processes were led by the two faculty PIs, two graduate research assistants, and various undergraduate research assistants. Once we verified the definition of an ‘event’, we developed an online instrument to code characteristics and details about all identified acts. This process, too, went through numerous revisions and updates as we refined our understanding of the events. All appropriate articles for 2001 from the 50 states and Washington D.C. were coded, drawn from a total of 13,864 newspaper articles. Additionally, we have completed an additional 10 states from 1991 and 13 states from 2011 with additional states currently in progress. In total, we coded 16,715 newspaper articles and preliminary analyses of the events for 2001 are now ongoing.

Our initial analyses identified 1192 Muslim hostility events having occurred in 2001, after removing identified duplicates, a major difficulty as the most notorious and violent events which were reported widely in many newspapers.  Consistent with our expectation and past evidence, the vast majority of these came after the September, 11 attacks. In 2001 exclusively, we identified 40 (3%) hostile events occurred before 9/11 while 97% (1152) of the events occurred after 9/11. The most common hostile events contained instances of interpersonal harassment and intimidation (71% of the post 9/11 “hostile events”), events which would rarely register in “hate crime” records. Property crimes (e.g. vandalism. arson, burglary) were next most common, followed closely by interpersonal assault.  Fifteen murders were reported, 14 of which came after 9/11.

Muslim advocacy events were almost twice and common as hostile events. The vast majority of the hostile events occurred in the several days after 9/11. There was a spike of Muslim advocacy events in the same period, but as hostile events became much less common in the months following 9/11 advocacy events continued to occur at a high rate. One of our original aims included analyzing the community context of both hostile and advocacy events which continues.

In addition to collecting, coding, and preliminary analyses of newspaper articles reported Muslim hostile acts as well as advocacy acts outlined above, this project has generated substantial outcomes with regard to training undergraduate researchers. Under the advisement of the two PIs, this project has supported one post-doctoral research associate, three graduate research assistants, and 15 undergraduate research assistants during the three years of funding. Additionally, our newspaper article collection process, collaboration with Newsbank, and event coding will serve as a guide for future researchers collecting newspaper event data on Muslim hostility and advocacy events as well as any other similar publically reported events.
